sections.title: Introduction
body: A stack is a linear data structure that follows the LIFO (Last In, First Out) principle.
In a stack, the element inserted last is the first one to be removed.
It can be implemented using arrays, linked lists, or dynamic memory structures.
All insertion and deletion operations occur only at one end, called the 'top' of the stack.
Stacks are widely used for undo/redo operations, expression evaluation, function call tracking, and backtracking algorithms.

sections.title: Characteristics
body: Follows LIFO order for both insertion and deletion.
Only one pointer (top) is used to track the last inserted element.
Efficient for operations that require reversing or backtracking.
Supports constant-time push and pop operations.

sections.title: Operations
body: Push: Inserts an element onto the top of the stack.
Pop: Removes the top element from the stack.
Peek/Top: Returns the top element without removing it.
isEmpty: Checks if the stack is empty.
isFull: Checks if the stack is full (in case of fixed-size stack).

sections.title: Types of Stacks
body: Static Stack: Implemented using arrays with fixed size.
Dynamic Stack: Implemented using linked lists, allowing flexible size.
Double-Ended Stack (Deque-based): Supports push/pop from both ends.
Min Stack: Special stack that supports retrieval of minimum element in O(1) time.
Multi-Stack: Implementing multiple stacks in a single array.

sections.title: Advantages
body: Simple and easy to implement.
Push and pop operations are very efficient (O(1)).
Excellent for problems involving recursion or nested operations.
Memory utilization is efficient in dynamic stack implementation.

sections.title: Disadvantages
body: Limited size in static stack implementation.
Stack overflow can occur if the stack exceeds its capacity.
Not suitable for random access because elements can only be accessed from the top.
Difficult to use for large datasets when using array-based implementation.

sections.title: Time Complexity
body: Push: O(1) — Only updates the top pointer.
Pop: O(1) — Removes the top element.
Peek: O(1) — Simply returns the top element.
Search: O(n) — Must check elements one by one.
Space Complexity: O(n) — Depends on the number of elements stored.

sections.title: Applications
body: Function call management in programming languages using the call stack.
Undo/redo functionality in text editors and design tools.
Expression evaluation such as postfix, prefix, and infix conversions.
Balanced parenthesis checking using stack operations.
Depth-First Search (DFS) for graph traversal.
Browser history management (back/forward operations).
Memory management and recursion handling.
